I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam  requested assistance from the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) in building the capacity of Viet Nam Electricity (formerly known 
as Electricity of Viet Nam [EVN]) in environmental management of thermal power plants (TPP), 
including air quality management, in Quang Ninh Province. The advisory technical assistance 
(TA) was included in the country strategy and program 2007–2010.1 The TA is programmed for 
ADB’s 2007 TA program for Viet Nam.  The Fact-Finding Mission visited Viet Nam in March 
2007  and  reached  an  understanding  with  the  Government  on  the  objective,  scope,  cost 
estimates, counterpart financing, and implementation arrangements for the TA.2  
 
2.  The TA will focus on strengthening EVN staff capacity in environmental management 
and adopting best environmental practices to ensure sustainable development of thermal power 
projects in Viet Nam. The TA will also assist the Department of Environment and Natural 
Resources (DONRE) of Quang Ninh Province in addressing air pollution problems due to power 
development and improving its capacity for managing air quality in the province.   
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Viet  Nam’s  rapid  economic  growth  of  7.5%  per  annum  over  the  past  decade  has 
contributed to the Government’s success in reducing the proportion of the population below the 
poverty line, from 58% in 1993 to 19% in 2006. The Government aims to maintain this level of 
economic growth until 2010, and to further reduce poverty to 15%. With continued economic 
growth comes an estimated 16% per annum increase in power demand.  Any shortage in power 
is most likely to result in slower economic growth and underachievement of the the poverty 
reduction targets.  To address power demand requirements, the Government prepared the 6th 
Power  Development  Master  Plan  (PDMP).  The  plan  identifies  the  need  for  new  power 
generation,  transmission,  and  distribution  projects  to  be  implemented  to  meet  the  nation’s 
growing power demands. To support the 6th PDMP, ADB and other development partners are 
preparing a major lending program to assist Viet Nam in meeting the power demand. For 
instance, Mong Duong TPP in Quang Ninh and Song Bung IV hydropower plant are two 
projects that are programmed for ADB financing in 2007. The country strategy and program for 
Viet Nam, 2007–2010, incorporates the environment as a crosscutting theme and proposes 
initiatives to assist in building the Government’s capacity in environmental management to 
ensure a sustainable high level of economic growth while at the same time providing financing 
support to the country’s infrastructure development.    
 
4.  Viet Nam’s power system has a total installed capacity of 11,340 megawatts (MW), of 
which almost 78% or 8,822 MW is generated by EVN. Around 61% of EVN’s installed capacity 
is with TPPs (coal-fired, oil-fired, and gas).3 EVN will continue to play a significant role in 
supplying the country’s power needs, even though in the Government’s proposed power sector 
reforms, private sector ownership of power generation will increase to about 30% by 2011. The 
daily operation of TPPs, especially those based on coal, has been contributing to environmental

problems and deteriorating air quality and public health in both urban and rural areas due to air 
emissions, waste generation, and inefficiency of plant operation.4  
 
5.  ADB’s  country  environmental  analysis  for  Viet  Nam5 found  that  the  environmental 
problems in existing TPPs were partly due to poor maintenance of equipment and out-of-date 
design and technology, and also to weak capacity and institutional systems for environmental 
management.6 In recognition of these issues, EVN’s management decided to introduce new 
combustion technology and design for its new coal-fired TPPs so as to use cleaner technologies 
and achieve higher thermal efficiencies, and to incorporate environmental abatement equipment 
in project designs to minimize adverse environmental impacts. For instance, the Mong Duong 
power plant will use circulating fluidized bed technology to efficiently burn domestic coal. The 
project is designed to ensure that emission standards for sulfur dioxide, nitrogen dioxide, and 
particulate matter are complied with.7 Further, EVN has also decided that new coal-fired power 
plants to be built in central and southern Viet Nam will all use supercritical boiler technologies 
and burn imported coal. The innovations will improve power plant efficiencies to around 44%–
47% compared with the traditional thermal efficiencies of 35%–37%. EVN staff will need to be 
trained in the use of these new technologies to maximize their environmental benefits. 
 
6.         To  further  address  environmental  issues  associated  with  power  development,  EVN 
established in 2005 a Science, Technology and Environment Department (STED) to provide 
corporate-wide advice on environmental management. The actual design of pollution control 
equipment and environmental assessment for TPPs during the planning and design period are 
carried  out  by  EVN’s  power  engineering  and  consulting  companies  (PECCs).  The 
implementation of environmental management plans during plant construction and operation 
rests  with  the  thermal  power  project  management  units  (TPPMU).  Experience  with  EVN’s 
environmental management at various stages of power plant development has shown that the 
design  capacity  of  PECCs  and  implementation  capacity  of  TPPMUs  on  environmental 
management are limited, and do not meet international standards. STED also lacks knowledge 
of best international practices in environmental management of TPPs, and so is not well-
equipped to give adequate suggestions and support to the PECCs and TPPMUs during project 
design and implementation. Often the results are project delays. To improve the situation, 
additional support to EVN is needed to strengthen its capacity for environmental management 
during project design and implementation.8  
 
7.  ADB has provided technical assistance to EVN in strategic environmental management 
and  environmental  management  for  hydropower  plant  development.9 The  Japan  Bank  for 
International Cooperation (JBIC) is also assisting EVN in developing a corporate environmental

skills in clean technology and pollution control practices for TPPs, is timely and complements

8.  Coal-fired TPPs emit sulfur dioxide, carbon dioxide, nitrogen oxide, and fine particulates. 
Some of these power plants, such as Pha Lai TPP, Quang Ninh TPP, and the planned Mong 
Duong TPP, are located in northern Viet Nam, specifically in Quang Ninh Province, where coal 
reserves are huge. Coal-fired power plants are expected to eventually account for 22% of Viet 
Nam’s total installed generating capacity by 2015 and 34% by 2020. These coal-fired power 
plants usually compound the air quality issues by contributing to high levels of sulfur dioxide, 
nitrogen oxide, and particulate matter on top of the dust generated by mining activities, which 
cause air quality to deteriorate and affect the health of people living in the vicinity.  
 
9.  Quang Ninh Province has the largest coal resources in Viet Nam. More than 100,000 
people are employed by the coal industry in the province, with many others employed in 
subsidiary and service industries related to coal. Coal mining activities have been affecting air 
quality in the province. Air pollution is caused mainly by coal dust, which results from blasting in 
the coal mines and the transporting of coal from the mines to coal processing plants, power 
plants, and ports. The suspended particulate matters, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen dioxide, and 
carbon monoxide in Quang Ninh are already at serious levels. The United Nations Development 
Programme conducted a study of the environmental issues of open-pit mining in Quang Ninh in 
1995, and identified a number of weaknesses in institutional capacity, which to date have not 
been adequately addressed. 
 
10.  To  improve  the  worsening  air  pollution  in  the  province,  the  Quang  Ninh  People’s 
Committee issued Order No. 1013 on 3 April 2006, which defined mitigation measures to be 
adopted to minimize air pollution caused by coal transportation. The Committee requested 
DONRE and the provincial police to strengthen law enforcement and to impose penalties for 
violations. Also in 2006, the Committee approved a budget for DONRE to establish laboratory 
facilities to improve air quality monitoring in the province. Quang Ninh DONRE acknowledges 
that its staff lacks the necessary technical skills and knowledge in air quality monitoring and 
management,  which  is  essential  for  it  to  monitor  the  implementation  of  environmental 
management plans and pollution control measures of mining companies and power plants in the 
province. 
 
11.  Both EVN and Quang Ninh DONRE urgently need technical support in strengthening 
their capacity to plan and implement environmental management strategies, and to manage 
TPP air quality and related activities. The proposed TA will demonstrate to both EVN and 
Quang Ninh DONRE the best practices in environmental management, and pollution control and 
monitoring in areas affected by a thermal power project and associated fuel exploitation and 
transportation activities.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The purpose of the TA is to assist EVN and Quang Ninh Provincial DONRE in building

13.  The proposed TA will address environmental management associated with coal-fired 
TPPs through two components. The expected outcome of component 1 will be building within 
EVN  adequate  capacity  and  technical  knowledge  of  pollution  control  and  environmental 
management  measures  associated  with  TPPs.  The  outcome  of  component  2  will  be  the 
strengthened capability of Quang Ninh DONRE in air quality management. The expected results 
of  component  1  are  (i)  improved  knowledge  in  environmental  planning  and  management 
strategies of staff in  TPPs of EVN, its associated institutions and organizations, including the 
TPPMUs, and PECCs; (ii) strengthened capacity of PECCs, TPPMUs, and TPPs in designing 
and  implementing  pollution  control  and  environmental  monitoring  measures;  (iii)  training 
materials including state-of-the-art knowledge and international best practices that can be used 
by EVN for its future training activities; and (iv) a medium-term capacity-building plan to sustain 
the benefits of the TA activities. For component 2, the expected results are (i) strengthened 
Quang Ninh DONRE’s capacity for managing air quality and controlling air pollution from TPPs 
and  mining  activities  in  the  province;  (ii) an  air  quality  management  plan  for Quang  Ninh 
Province including action items, budget estimates, resource requirements, and implementation 
plan; and (iii) baseline data in air quality and public health monitoring in the vicinity of the Mong 
Duong TPP.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  Various methods such as desk reviews, field surveys, workshops, policy dialogues, and 
consultations will be used to obtain the TA outputs.  The TA will be implemented over 12 
months by a team of consultants.   
 
15.  For component 1, EVN has selected Mong Duong TPPMU as the Implementing Agency 
for  the  TA  activities.  TA  consultants  will  carry  out  these  major  activities:  (i)  assess  the 
weaknesses and strengths of EVN in implementing environmental management measures for 
TPPs, with particular focus on clean technology, pollution control equipment, and environmental 
monitoring;  (ii)  considering  government  legislation,  corporate  policies,  and  development 
partners’ environmental requirements, identify training needs in environmental management for 
EVN staff; (iii) prepare training materials, which will include, but will not be limited to, state-of-
the-art clean technology, international best practices on the use of pollution control equipment, 
and environmental monitoring of TPPs; (iv) organize training workshops for various levels of 
EVN staff; (v) organize an international training course for selected EVN staff in a facility similar 
to Mong Duong power plant in the Asia and Pacific region for the trainees to learn how state-of-
art cleaner technology and environmental management practices in coal-fired power plants are  
undertaken; (vi) prepare a medium-term capacity-building plan for environmental management 
for EVN; and (vii) evaluate the effectiveness of the TA and suggest follow-up activities in a 
medium-term capacity-building plan.   
 
16.  For component 2, the TA consultants will (i) review and assess air pollution sources and 
management  issues  in  Quang  Ninh  Province;  (ii)  assess  the  weaknesses  of  Quang  Ninh 
DONRE  in  establishing  baseline  data  and  monitoring  air  quality  and  related  public  health 
parameters; (iii) make site visits to open-pit coal mines and associated coal processing and 
transportation activities, and assess the status of air pollution in those activities; (iv) establish 
two air quality stations in the impact zone of Mong Duong power plant  to collect baseline data; 
(v) collect baseline data on public health to be used for monitoring the incidence of respiratory 
diseases in Mong Duong ward and Cam Hai commune in Cam Pha district, which are the 
impact zones of the Mong Duong power complex; (vi) prepare an air quality management plan 
for Quang Ninh Province through a participatory consultation process; and (vii) conduct training 
for Quang Ninh DONRE and its district officials. Quang Ninh DONRE will hold stakeholder

5  
meetings  with  district  officials  and  representatives  of  Cam  Pha  district  and  coal  mining 
companies, to solicit their views on the TA activities and planned outputs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA total cost is estimated at $720,000 equivalent. The Government has requested 
ADB to finance $600,000 equivalent. This amount will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Government of France and administered by ADB. The Government of Viet Nam will finance the 
remaining $120,000 equivalent through in-kind contribution. Detailed cost estimates and the 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  EVN will be the Executing Agency (EA) and TPPMU1 the Implementing Agency (IA) for 
component 1, and Quang Ninh People’s Committee will be the EA and Quang Ninh DONRE the 
IA for component 2. The TA will be implemented over  12 months, from  October 2007 to 
September  2008,  and  will  require  a  total  of  38  person-months  of  consulting  services—15 
person-months international and 23 person-months national.  A consulting firm will be selected 
in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (February 2007, as amended 
from time to time). Resource persons will be engaged as lecturers on specific topics. The 
simplified technical proposal procedure will be used for selecting the consulting firm on the 
quality- and-cost-based selection process at a quality-cost ratio of 80:20. The outline terms of 
reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
19.  The trainees in component 1 will be managers and environment staff from seven TPPs 
and  six  TPPMUs,  environmental  and  design  engineers  from  4  PECCs,  and  environment 
specialists  in  EVN  headquarters.  Approximately  50  persons  who  are  involved  in  plant 
management  and  are  directly  responsible  for  environmental  design,  management,  and 
monitoring will be selected to attend in-country training. International training will be provided to 
five  persons,  including  environment  specialists  in  STED  and  the  project  manager  and 
environment specialists from Mong Duong TPPMU. 
 
20.  The trainees in component 2 will include environment officers from Quang Ninh DONRE 
and Quang Ninh provincial districts. Approximately 20 persons will receive in-country training, 
and 4 officials from Quang Ninh DONRE will receive international training. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 to the Government 
of Viet Nam to be financed on a grant basis by the Government of France for Capacity Building 
on Environmental Management to the Power Sector, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.   The technical assistance (TA) will require 38 person-months of consulting services (15 
person-months international and 23 person-months national). A consulting firm will be recruited 
to provide a team of experts with appropriate expertise to undertake various tasks. The TA will 
be completed in 12 months. 
 
2.   The team leaders of components 1 and 2 could be the same specialist if he/she has the 
appropriate qualifications and expertise. The number of person-months for each specialist is 
indicative and can be adjusted to best suit the team’s need to accomplish the TA assignments. 
Resource persons will be engaged as necessary to conduct trainings. 
 
A.  Component  1:  Capacity  Building  on  Environmental  Management  for  Viet  Nam 
Electricity (EVN) 
 
  1.   Environment Specialist/Team Leader (international, 5 person-months) 
 
3.   Qualifications.  The  specialist/team  leader  (TL)  preferably  will  have  a  postgraduate 
degree in environmental management, environmental science, or environmental engineering; 
and at least 10 years of working and capacity-building training experience in developing and 
implementing an environmental management system, environmental auditing, environmental 
quality management planning, and pollution control in thermal power plants (TPPs). Extensive 
working experience with international teams in developing countries in Asia, preferably in Viet 
Nam, is essential. 
 
4.   Specific Tasks. The TL will supervise and coordinate other consultant team members’ 
activities and be responsible for the timely delivery of the team’s outputs. He/she will have 
overall responsibility for delivering the outputs of component 1 with the assistance of the team 
members. The scope of work follows. 
 
(i)  Prepare a work plan for the team and discuss with the executing agency (EA) 
and stakeholders to confirm the work plan and related methodology, scope of 
work  and  implementation  schedule  at  an  inception  meeting;  and  make 
adjustments, when necessary, during TA implementation. 
(ii)  Review  the  summary  environmental  impact  assessment  (SEIA)  and  
environmental management plan (EMP) of the Mong Duong TPP, assess  the 
human resources of thermal power plant management unit 1 (TPPMU1), and 
conduct a training workshop for TPPMU1 on EMP implementation. 
(iii)  Identify training needs in environmental management, pollution control practices, 
and capacity to design these measures in projects at various levels of Electricity 
of  Viet  Nam  (EVN),  including  EVN’s  Science,  Technology  and  Environment 
Department, TPPMUs, power engineering consulting companies (PECCs), and 
TPPs; and prepare an outline of the training materials for EVN and the Asian 
Development Banks’s (ADB) review and approval. 
(iv)  Prepare training materials for EVN staff to strengthen their knowledge of state-of-
the-art TPP planning and management, clean technologies, pollution control, and 
environmental management and monitoring. The number of trainees is around 50.

  persons, for ADB’s review and approval before conducting the training program. 
(vi)  Conduct  capacity-building  training  workshops  for  50  staff  members  of  EVN, 
PECCs, TPPMUs, and TPPs.

(vii)  Plan an international training program on environmental management of TPPs 
for five persons. The training will be conducted in a power plant in the Asia and 
Pacific region. EVN will identify the power plant in consultation with ADB and 
coordinate the logistic arrangement.  
(viii)  Formulate  a  mechanism  for  monitoring  and  evaluation  to  assess  the 
effectiveness  of  the  capacity-building  training,  and  prepare  a  medium-term 
capacity-building plan on environmental management to ensure the sustainability 
of the TA activities, with inputs from other consultants. 
(ix)  Coordinate with and guide other team members to ensure the quality and timely

the TA. 
(xi)  Prepare inception, interim, and final reports and respective review workshops as

  2.   Power Engineer (international, 3 person-months) 
 
5.   Qualifications. The international power engineer will have a university or postgraduate 
degree  in  power  engineering,  mechanical  engineering,  energy  economics,  power  plant 
development, or energy efficiency and conservation. He/she will have at least 10 years of 
extensive  working  experience  in  managing  technology  development  for  TPPs,  fuel/energy 
efficiency survey, and audit in power plants or industrial factories; and optimization of operation 
and  maintenance  of  power  plants  or  industrial  factories.  Work  experience  in  developing 
countries in Asia will be an advantage. 
 
6.   Specific Tasks. The international power engineer will undertake these tasks. 
  
(i)  Work  with  the  TL  to  develop  the  work  plan  and  training  programs,  and 
methodology for evaluating the effectiveness of the capacity-building activities. 
(ii)  Prepare training materials on operation and maintenance of best coal-burn power 
generation technologies, such as circulating fluidized bed and supercritical boiler, 
from the viewpoint of environmental management. 
(iii)  Provide  inputs  to  the  TL  to  prepare  and  conduct  the  training  program  and 
materials, and conduct related training. Focus of the inputs will be on state-of-
the-art knowledge and technology of thermal power generation, thermal pollution 
control, and fly ash management. 
(iv)  Assist the TL to prepare the international training program. 
(v)  Perform other tasks that will be reasonably required to achieve the objectives of 
the TA.  
 
  3.   Environment Specialist (national, 6 person-months) 
 
7.   Qualifications. The national environment specialist will have a university degree in 
environmental management, environmental engineering, or environmental science. He/she will 
have extensive work experience in environmental auditing, power plant-related environmental 
impact assessment (EIA), or pollution control and monitoring; or be familiar with the operation 
and  management  of  power  plants  or  industrial  factories.  Familiarity  with  international  aid 
agencies’ project implementation procedures is required. 
 
8.   Specific Tasks. The specialist will carry out the following work under the guidance of 
the TL.

(i)  Collect  related  government  regulations  and  standards  or  environmental 
management  data  and  information  of  EVN  and  its  TPPs,  with  a  focus  on 
controlling pollution, including that of air, wastewater, and solid wastes. Translate 
relevant information into English as needed for the TA’s uses. 
(ii)  Assist the TL to conduct the training needs assessment and prepare the training 
program and materials. 
(iii)  Perform other tasks that will be reasonably required to achieve the objectives of 
the TA. 
 
  4.   Power Engineer (national, 4 person-months) 
 
9.   Qualifications. The national power engineer will have a university degree in power 
engineering, mechanical engineering, energy economics, or power plant development. He/she 
will  have  an  extensive  working  experience  in  the  operation  of  TPPs,  environmental 
management system, fuel/energy  efficiency survey, and  audit in power plants or industrial 
factories,  and/or  optimization  of  operation  and  maintenance  of  power  plants  or  industrial 
factories.  Familiarity  with  international  aid  agencies’  project  implementation  procedures  is 
required. 
 
10.   Specific Tasks. The national power engineer will assist the international power engineer 
to carry out the following tasks. 
 
(i)  Collect regulations and data on thermal pollution, and current practices in thermal 
pollution control and fly ash management in EVN’s TPPs. Translate relevant 
information into English as needed for the TA’s uses. 
(ii)  Assist in assessing the strengths and weaknesses of EVN’s capacity for TPP 
planning, design, operation, management, and pollution control and monitoring. 
(iii)  Assist in preparing the training program and materials, and in conducting related 
training. Focus of the inputs will be on state-of-the-art knowledge and technology 
of thermal power generation, thermal pollution control, and fly ash management. 
(iv)  Undertake other tasks that will be reasonably required to achieve the objectives 
of the TA. 
 
B.  Component 2: Capacity Building on Air Quality Management for the Department of 
Natural Resources and Environment (DONRE), Quang Ninh Province 
 
  1.   Environment Specialist (international, 5 person-months) 
 
11.   Qualifications. The international environment specialist will have a postgraduate degree 
in environmental engineering, environmental science, or air quality management; and at least 
10 years of extensive experience in air pollution control, preferably in the mining and power 
industries, air emission survey and monitoring, and air quality planning and management in 
developing countries. Working experience in Viet Nam is essential. 
 
12.   Specific  Tasks.  The  international  environment  specialist  will supervise  the  national 
specialists’ work and have overall responsibility for delivering the outputs of component 2. 
He/she will undertake the following tasks.

to  confirm  the  work  plan  and  related  methodology,  scope  of  work,  and

necessary, during TA implementation. 
(ii)  Using the Mong Duong EIA prepared under ADB TA 46701 as a reference and in 
consultation with EVN and DONRE, prepare a monitoring plan for particulates for 
the Mong Duong power plant project area. 
(iii)  Set up two monitoring stations for particulates in two districts near Mong Duong 
power plant site, and train two district officials to monitor particulate matters and 
other air quality issues.  
(iv)  Review relevant reports prepared by other aid agencies such as United Nations 
Development  Programme  and  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency,  and 
assess current status and issues of air quality and air pollution sources in Quang 
Ninh Province, and their impacts on public health. 
(v)  Review Quang Ninh DONRE’s laboratory equipment and human resources, and 
prepare an ambient air quality monitoring and emission inventory plan for the 
province to be implemented by DONRE during the TA implementation period. 
(vi)  Assess  the  weaknesses  and  needs  of  Quang  Ninh  DONRE  in  air  quality 
management, and prepare a training program on air quality management for 
DONRE. 
(vii)  Develop an air quality management plan for Quang Ninh Province, which will 
include, but will not be limited to, the following: (a) emission inventories in the 
province (stationary and mobile sources), (b) short- and medium-term emission 
forecasts based on major economic activities in the province, (c) short- and 
medium-term  air  quality  management  strategies,  (d)  legislative  requirements 
(current and future), and (e) implementation plan. 
(viii)  Organize discussion meetings and a workshop for Quang Ninh DONRE and 
stakeholders to review and comment on the air quality management plan and to 
disseminate the results. 
(ix)  With the inputs of other consultants, prepare training materials and conduct a 
training workshop for concerned DONRE and commune staff to strengthen their 
capacity for air quality management and public health monitoring. 
(x)  Plan a study tour on air quality management for two Quang Ninh provincial 
officials. 
(xi)  Formulate a mechanism for monitoring and evaluating the effectiveness of the 
capacity-building training and the air quality management plan. 
(xii)  Coordinate with and guide other team members to ensure the quality and timely 
delivery of the team’s outputs.  
(xiii)  Undertake other tasks that will be reasonably required to achieve the objectives 
of the TA. 
(xiv)  Prepare inception, interim, and final reports as per contractual requirements.

mining, geology, or occupational health and safety; and work experience in environmental 
management for open mining. He/she will have field experience in mining management in 
developing countries in Asia, preferably in Viet Nam.
